entry.definition: Database relationship in which one instance of entity A is associated with one instance of entity B.

Database relationship in which one instance of entity A can correspond to many instances of entity B, but an instance of B can correspond to only one A , for example, a grade has many students, but each student is in only one grade.
A complete pathname that is independent of the current file location. Includes the root directory of a file or complete URL of a web page.
Measurement of the amount of time it takes the process to read data, instructions, and information from memory.
Is available when the decision-maker needs it.
Basic properties of a database management system which allow safe sharing of information: Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, and Durability.
Search type seeking documents "about this."
A sequence of well-defined instructions designed to accomplish a certain task.
Continuous (wave form) signals.
A third-party organization that manages and distributes software and services on the Web, so programs are run from the Internet rather than installed on the user's computer.
Software programs designed to make users more productive and/or assist them with personal tasks.
Component of a processor that performs arithmetic, comparison, and other operations.
A set of elements grouped together.
The second generation of programming languages in which a programmer write instructions using symbolic instruction codes, or meaningful abbreviations and codes.
An encryptions scheme in which different keys are used for encryption and decryption.
A named field in a database, also a column.
Process of entering any sound, such as speech, music, and sound effects, into the computer.
A log maintained by the computer that records in a file both successful and unsuccessful access attempts.
Duplicate or copy of a file, program, or disk that can be used if the original is lost, damaged or destroyed.
The amount of data that can travel over a communications channel in a fixed amount of time.
Built-in software that determines what a computer can do without accessing any programs and controls start-up.
A software architecture in which tasks are saved up and executed all at once
Opening inside the system unit in which additional equipment can be installed.
A tech buzzword that signifies a stand-alone, specialized software program designed to excel at a particular task.
See bit.
Number system used by computers that has just two unique digits, 0 and 1, called bits.

A device that authenticates a person's identity by translating a personal characteristic, such a fingerprint, into a digital code that is then compared with a digital code stored in the computer verifying a physical or behavioral characteristic.
The smallest unit of data a computer can process, equal to 1/8 of a byte. Bit is short for binary digit.
A retrieval system using Boolean operators (AND, OR, NOT) which can be accurate and efficient, but sometimes returns nonexistent relationships.
Type of media that transmits multiple signals simultaneously.
See disk cache.
A program error.
Process of writing on an optical disc.

In a computer, the electrical channel that transfers electronic bits internally within the circuitry of a computer, allowing the devices both inside and attached to the system unit to communicate with each other. In a network, the physical cable that connects the computers and other devices in a bus network. A network has a bus topology if all the computers attach to the same cable.
Application software that assists people in becoming more efficient and effective while performing their daily business activities.
Eight bits that are grouped together as a unit. A byte provides enough different combinations of 0s and 1s to represent 256 individual characters.
An object-oriented programming language based on C++ and used for Web applications and XML-based Web services.
An object-oriented programming language that extends the C programming language, often used to develop database and Web applications.
Programming language designed for writing systems software, and today used for programs including operating systems and application software.
Area of memory that stores the contents of frequently used data or instructions.
The number of bytes (characters) a storage medium can hold.
See processor.
An authorized person or company that issues and verifies digital certificates.
A technology used in web servers to generate a web page in response to a user input.
Small piece of semi conducting material, usually silicon, on which integrated circuits are etched.
A system in which there is a fixed connection between two points on a network, through which a transmission is sent.
Network in which one or more computers act as a server, and the other computers on the network request services from the server.
Computer on a network that requests resources from the server.
One tick of the system clock.
Pace of the system clock, measured by the number of ticks (clock cycles) per second.
Programming language designed for business applications.
The programming language used to write a program.
A separate program that converts the entire source program into machine language, or an object code, before executing it.
A reduction in size of a picture so that it takes up fewer bits.
A series of instructions that directs a computer to perform tasks.
A potentially damaging computer program that infects a computer and negatively affects the way the computer works without the user's knowledge or permission.

Electronic device, operating under the control of instructions stored in its own memory, that can accept data, process the data according to specified rules, produce results, and store the results for future use.
Database issue that arises when multiple people have shared access to the same database
A type of programming control structure in which instructions are contingent on a condition being true.
Device that joins a cable to a peripheral.
Component of a processor that directs and coordinates most of the operations in the computer.
A small text file that a web server stores on your computer which web applications use to identify users and customize web pages.
Gives more value than it costs to produce.
See processor.
Someone who tries to access a computer or network illegally.
An acronym for four basic concepts of graphical design: Contrast, Repetition, Alignment and Proximity.
Used in web page design to separate the content and style of a web page from its appearance

Method of attaching multiple peripherals in which the first USB device connects to the USB port on the computer, the second USB device connects to the first USB device, the third USB device connects to the second USB device, and so on.
Part of a bus that transfers actual data.
A window that provides areas for entering or changing data in a database.
A collection of related records stored on a storage medium such as a hard disk, CD, or DVD.
The quality of the data, i.e., the quantity of errors.
Finding patterns and relationship s among data.
Rules and standards that define how a database organizes data.

In the context of an IR system, consists mainly of determining which documents of a collection contain the keywords in the user query which, most frequently, is not enough to satisfy the user information need.
The kind of data a field can contain, such as text (alphanumeric), numeric, date
A huge database that stores and manages the data required to analyze historical and current transactions.
Pieces of information, including text, numbers, images, audio, and video.
Application software that allows users to create, access, and manage a database (i.e., Microsoft Access).

A collection of data organized in a manner that allows access, retrieval, and use of that data, or a large, integrated collection of data organized to support access which models some aspects of reality.
Process of converting unreadable characters into readable data.
That part of the Web which is not indexed by search engines because its pages are generated in response to queries and are not linked to other pages.
An assault on a computer whose purpose is to disrupt access to the web.
On-screen work area that has a graphical user interface.
See programmer.
A notice that guarantees a user or a web site is legitimate.
Access and copy controls placed on a digital work.
Encrypted code that a person, Web site, or company attaches to an electronic message to verify the identity of the information sender.
Representation of data using only two discrete states: on (1) and off (0).
See random access.
A method for studying human-computer interaction in which the evaluator observes users interacting with the system.
Memory chips on a hard disk that store frequently accessed items such as data, instructions and information. Also called a buffer.
1998 act which makes it illegal to circumvent antipiracy schemes in commercial software; outlaws sale of devices that copy software illegally.
Terms that define a well-formed XML document.
A system that links domain names to IP addresses.
A metadata standard for describing digital resources.
Programmed formula that the recipient of data uses to decrypt cipher-text.
The process of converting readable data into unreadable characters to prevent unauthorized access.
The science of incorporating comfort, efficiency, and safety into the design of the workplace.
An action which triggers the execution of code. Examples: onMouseover, onClick.
Process of a computer carrying out the instructions in a program.
Separate freestanding hard disk that connects with a cable to a USB port of FireWire port on the system unit.
A unique identifier for each field in a database.
The maximum number of characters a field can contain.
An "atomic" unit of data.
A security system consisting of hardware and/or software that prevents unauthorized access to data, information, and storage media on a network.
ROM chips that contain permanently written data, instructions, or information, recorded on the chips when they were manufactured.
Type of non-volatile memory that can be erased electronically and rewritten.
Portable storage medium that consists of a thin, circular flexible plastic Mylar film with a magnetic coating, enclosed in a square shaped plastic shell.
A field in a relational database that matches the primary key of another table.
Evaluation done while a system is being developed, designed to inform its design.
Process of dividing a disk into tracks and sectors so the operating system can store and locate data and information on the disk.
Software provided at no cost to use by an individual or company.
Reusable code for doing a single task which takes in one or more parameters and returns a single value.
A computing phrase meaning roughly "the accuracy of a computer's output depends on the accuracy of the input."
An image compression strategy which converts images to a 256-color palette.
Exactly 1,073,741,824 bytes (2 to the power of 30), often rounded to 1 billion.
One billion ticks of the system clock per second.
Type of user interface that allows a user to interact with software using text, graphics, and visual images, such as icons. See from GUI.
Software that helps groups of people work together on projects and share information over a network.
Printed information that exists physically and is a more permanent form of output than that presented on a display device (soft copy).
Type of storage device that contains one or more inflexible, circular platters that store data, instructions and information.
Electric, electronic, and mechanical components contained in a computer.
A programming language in which each language instruction typically equates to multiple machine instructions.
A markup language for encoding information to be read by humans.
A protocol for transferring data between machines on the Internet.
A compression strategy in which fewer bits are used to represent common colors.
A subset of standard generalized markup language used to author web pages. HTML specifies how text is formatted in web browsers.
A small image displayed on the screen that represents a program, a document, or some other object.
A graphical image that points to a Web address.
A collection of picture elements.
A phrase coined after World War II to describe the challenges resulting from a rapid increase in scientific progress and scientific publications.
Series of input, process, output, and storage activities performed by a computer.

Deals with the representation, storage, organization of, and access to information items. The representation and organization of the information items should provide the user with easy access to the information in which he is interested.
Collection of hardware, software, data, people, and procedures that work together to produce quality information
Processed data that is organized, meaningful, and useful, including documents, audio, images, and video.
Any hardware component that allows users to enter date and instructions into a computer.
Data entered into a computer system.
Steps that tell the computer how to perform a particular task.
The rights to which creators are entitled for their work on unique and original ideas, inventions, writings, art, processes, company names and logos.
A number that identifies each connection to a network. It takes the form of four numbers separated by periods.
Worldwide collection of networks that connects millions of businesses, government agencies, educational institutions, and individuals.
The ability of different computer systems and programs to work together.
A network that is set up for internal use within an organization.
A type of programming control structure in which instructions are repeated until a condition is met.
A small Java program that runs inside another program such as a Web browser.
An object-oriented programming language developed by Sun Microsystems.
An interpreted language that allows a programmer to add dynamic content and interactive elements to a web page.
In SQL, associates records from two tables so information can be retrieved.
An image compression strategy which uses mathematical curves (discrete cosine transform) to approximate changes in the image.
A large number (greater than 1024 bits) used for encryption and decryption.
Exactly 1,024 bytes (2 to the power of 10).
Search type concerned with locating an item known to exist
The time it takes a signal to travel from one location to another on a network.
The right to use the software; you do not own the software.
Process of a computer copying a program from storage to memory.
Network that connects computers and devices in a limited geographical area such as a home, school computer laboratory, office building, or closely positioned group of buildings.
A listing of activities that change the contents of the database.
A form of compression in which the original image can be reconstructed in exact original form.
A form of compression in which the original image cannot be reconstructed.
A programming language that is machine dependent, or runs on only one particular type of computer.

A low-level, first generation programming language, and the only language the computer directly recognizes, consisting of binary digits that correspond to the off and on electrical states of a computer.
Storage medium that uses magnetic particles to store items such as data, instructions and information on a disk's surface.
Large, expensive, powerful computer that can handle hundreds or thousands of connected users simultaneously, storing tremendous amounts of data, instructions, and information.
A type of database relationship in which multiple matches are possible between items A and B and between B and A.
An XML language for defining mathematic formulas.
Exactly 1,048,576 bytes (2 to the power of 20), often rounded to 1 million.
Conceived by Vannevar Bush and foreshadowing development of hypertext and information retrieval.
Cache that helps speed the processes of a computer by storing frequently used instructions and data.
Small circuit board that houses RAM chips and is held in a memory slot on the motherboard.
Slots on the motherboard that hold memory modules.
Electronic components in a computer that store instructions waiting to be executed and data needed by those instructions.
Literally "data about data," a set of data that describes and gives information about other data.
One millionth of a second.
Radio waves that provide a high-speed signal transmission.
Server that is more powerful and larger than a workstation computer, typically supporting several hundred and sometimes up to a few thousand connected computers at the same time.
Communications device that converts a computer's digital signals to analog signals.
An observation made in 1965 by Gordon Moore that the number of transistors on a chip (and thus its speed) doubles roughly every 18 months.
Main circuit board of the system unit, which has some electronic components attached to it and others built into it.
An audio compression standard that eliminates frequencies that are difficult for humans to hear.
A video compression standard that sends entire images interspersed with alterations to that image.
Any application that combines text, graphics, audio, and video.
One billionth of a second.
Layout of computers and devices in a communications network.
Collection of computers and devices connected together via communications devices and transmission media, allowing computers to share resources.
System that attempts to imitate the behavior of the human body.
A process of organizing a database to remove ambiguous relationships between data and minimize data redundancy.
Stores data in objects, items that contain data, and actions that read or process that data
An event driven programming language, such as Java, C++, and C#.
Describes the state of a computer when it is connected to a network.
A vocabulary of terms whose meaning is formally defined.
Software provided for use, modification, and redistribution.
Set of programs that coordinates all the activities among computer hardware devices.
Optical reader technology that involves reading typewritten, computer-printed or hand-printed characters from ordinary documents and translating the images to a form that a computer can process.
Type of storage medium that consists of a flat, round, portable disc made of metal, plastic and lacquer that is written on and read by a laser.
Arranged to suit the needs and requirements of the decision maker.
Any hardware component that conveys information to one or more people.
Data that has been processed into a useful form.
Mass produced, copyrighted retail software that meets the needs of a variety of users, not just a single user or company.
A system in which transmissions are broken up into pieces and routed separately.
Type of interface that connects devices to the system unit by transferring more than one bit at a time.
Processing method that uses multiple processors simultaneously to execute a program in order to speed processing times.
2001 law which gives law enforcement the right to monitor people's activities, including Web and email habits.
The destructive event or prank a virus program is intended to deliver.
A software architecture in which all data and computation are distributed
Device that connects to a system unit and is controlled by the processor in the computer.
Exactly 1,125,899,906,842,624 bytes (2 to the power of 50), often rounded to 1 quadrillion.
Scam in which a perpetrator sends an official looking email that attempts to obtain your personal and financial information.
The smallest element in an electronic image. Short for picture element.
Point at which a peripheral attaches to a system unit so it can send data to or receive information from the computer.
The fraction of results retrieved by the search which are relevant. A measure of the search's success.
In a relational database, a column or set of columns that uniquely identifies each record in a field.
The key known only by oneself and used for decryption.
Often called a third-generation language, it uses a series of English-like words to write instructions (PRINT means to print) or assigns names to a sequence of instructions called a procedure.
A programming paradigm which groups instructions into meaningful functions (examples: C, Pascal, Perl).
Electronic component on a computer's motherboard that interprets and carries out the basic instructions that operate the computer. Also called the CPU or central processing unit.
See software.
Person who writes and modifies computer programs. See from developer.
A set of words, symbols, and codes that enables a programmer to communicate instructions to a computer.
In SQL, specifies a subset of columns from which information will be retrieved
A type of search in which a static query is matched against newly-updated documents. Example: filter on incoming email.
The key known by others and used for encryption.
A software program that is not copyrighted.
Simple, English-like statements that allow users to specify the data to display, print, or store.
A request for specific data from the database.

Type of memory that can be read from and written to by the processor and other devices. Programs and data are loaded into RAM from storage devices such as a hard disk and remain in RAM as long as the computer has continuous power.

Type of data access in which the storage device can locate a particular data item or file immediately, without having to move consecutively through items stored in front of the desired data item or file.
A retrieval system which assigns each returned documents a relevance ranking and places the most relevant first.t
A software development model which uses a partially-functional prototype to refine the system requirements before expanding functionality
A type of image which is a bitmap and describes the contents of the image.
A framework for describing and interchanging metadata.
Process of transferring data, instructions and information from a storage medium into memory.
Type of nonvolatile memory that is used to store permanent data and instructions.
An XML format for distributing news headlines on the Web.
The fraction of relevant results which were returned by the search, out of all relevant results. A measure of the search's success.
Device that accepts the transmission of data, instructions, or information.
A collection of related fields.
A removable disk that contains an uninfected copy of key operating system commands and startup information that enables the computer to restart correctly.
Uses logs and/or backups to restore a destroyed or damaged database.
The number of times per second a monitor redraws an image on the screen.
A database that stores data in tables that consist of rows and columns.
A connection within the data.
A partial path that is relative to the current file location.
A measure of the effectiveness of the results returned by a search.
The number of horizontal and vertical pixels in a display device.
The time in milliseconds (ms) that it takes to turn a pixel on or off.
In SQL, retrieves only records matching particular criteria.
The process by which records are converted to a new database system.
A type of search in which queries are matched against information already on the Web. Example: Google, Yahoo searches.
Protocol that defines how a network uses radio signals to communicate with a tag placed in or attached to an object, animal, or person.
A network has a ring topology if a cable forms a closed loop (ring) with all computers and devices arranged along the ring. Data is transmitted around the ring unidirectionally.
Process of copying an individual song from a purchased audio CD and converting it to a digital format.
Process of using software.
A compression strategy in which the number of consecutive pixels of the same color are recorded.
The small arcs into which tracks on a disk are divided.
Device that initiates instructions to transmit data, instructions, or information.
Type of data access in which the storage device reads or writes data consecutively.
A type of programming control structure in which instructions are performed one after another.
Type of interface that connects a device to the system unit by transmitting data one bit at a time.
Computer that controls access to the hardware, software, and other resources on a network and provides a centralized storage area for programs, data, and information.
Copyrighted software distributed at no cost for a trial period.
Programming language used to integrate multimedia with text, audio, and video using XML.
The unauthorized and illegal duplication of copyrighted software.
Series of instructions that tells a computer what to do and how to do it. See from program.
Term used to refer to components that consist entirely of electronic components and contain no moving parts.
Document that contains the original form of data to be processed.
The program that contains the language instructions, or code, to be converted to machine language.
Unsolicited email message or newsgroup posting sent to many recipients or newsgroups at once.
A development model which stresses user testing, revision, and redesign
A program placed on a computer without the user's knowledge that secretly collects information about the user.
A network has a star topology if all the computers attach directly to a hub.
Hardware used to record (write and/or read) items to and from storage media.
The physical material on which a computer keeps data, instructions and information.
Playing audio or video on a computer over the Internet.
A document whose structure conforms to a certain set of rules.
A query language that allows users to manage, update, and retrieve data, using special keywords and rules that users include in SQL statements.
A type of evaluation concerned with overall effectiveness of a system.
Fastest, most powerful, and most expensive computer, capable of processing more than 100 trillion instructions in a single second.
That part of the Web which is indexed by search engines.
An encryption scheme in which the same key is used both for encryption and decryption
A set of grammar and rules that specify how to write instructions for a computer program.
Small quartz crystal circuit that is used by the processor to control the timing of all computer operations.
The interface between the user, the application software, and the computer's hardware.
Case that contains the electronic components of a computer that are used to process data.
A collection of related records.
Magnetically coated ribbon of plastic capable of storing large amounts of data and information at a low cost.
Exactly 1,099,511,627,776 bytes (2 to the power of 40), often rounded to one trillion.
A method for studying human-computer interaction in which users speak their thoughts while interacting with the system.
ramming languages such as C and Java which are designed to be easier for humans to understand than machine or assembly language.
Has a deadline or time period suited to its use.
A software architecture in which all users use the same machine
Network standard in which computers and devices on the network share or pass a special signal, called a token, in a unidirectional manner and in a preset order.
Price of running software including acquisition costs and "hidden" costs such as planning, installation, integration, migration, maintenance, and staff training.
A design concept stating that people transfer their knowledge and expectations from familiar objects to new ones.
The speed at which data, instructions and information transfer to and from a device.
The amount of time it takes for data to be transferred from one place to another.
Element of an integrated circuit that can act as an electronic switch that opens or closes the circuit for electrical charges.
Network standard, specifically a protocol, that defines how messages (data) are routed from one end of a network to the other, ensuring that the data arrives correctly.
Materials or substances capable of carrying one or more signals in a communications channel.
A virus that hides within or looks like a legitimate program. Unlike a virus or worm, a Trojan horse does not replicate itself to other computers.
A company or person you believe will not send a virus-infected file knowingly.
A row in a database.
16-bit coding scheme that has the capability of representing more than 65,000 characters and symbols.
A scheme for referencing the specific location of a resource.
Has meaning to the person who receives it.
Anyone who communicates with a computer or utilizes the information it generates.
Type of system software that allows a user to perform maintenance-type tasks usually related to managing a computer, its devices, or its programs. See from utility.
See utility program.
The process of comparing data with a set of rules or values to find out if the data is correct.
An instruction which declares a variable in JavaScript.
A type of image composed of mathematical curves, describing how to draw the image.
Can be proven as correct or incorrect.
A network that uses the public infrastructure but maintains privacy through access control or encryption.
An e-mail message that warns users of a nonexistent virus, worm, or Trojan horse.
A known specific pattern of virus code security.
A design concept stating that the fundamental properties of an object determine how it is used.
A language that provides a visual or graphical interface for creating source code.
Type of memory that loses its contents when a computer's power is turned off.
A development model which stresses upfront investment in needs analysis and design
Application software that exists on a Web site.
Network that covers a large geographic area (such as a city, country, or the world) using a communications channel that combines many types of media such as telephone lines, cables, and radio waves.
Number of bits a computer can interpret and execute at a given time.
Worldwide collection of electronic documents called Web pages, the Web is one of the more popular services on the Internet.
A virus that copies itself repeatedly, using up resources and possibly shutting down the computer or network.
Process of transferring data, instructions and information from memory to a storage medium.
Just like HTML, but based on XML rules to support integration of different data in the same document.
A standard for exchanging structured data.
Language for converting one XML document into another.
